text:
PROFESSOR: Now it's my pleasure
to introduce the first guest lecturer in the
[INAUDIBLE] series

with Professor Drew Endy. And what he's going to
tell us about or help us do

is build up our
understanding of how a cell does what it does by
describing in these terms how

cells, cellular processes
are the result of all the algorithms. And he's going to give us
examples of some of these

and then tell you, once
you understand what some of these algorithms
are, how you can use
it to do interesting biology. Drew. DREW ENDY: Thanks. Thanks, Paul. Morning.

As Paul just said, I'm going to
talk about two things, right? The first thing I'm
going to talk about today is the ideas that cells
themselves do computation

and how this might
be interesting to you as a scientist or an engineer,
thinking about biology,

and getting a better handle
on what biological systems do. I hope to dispense with
that in maybe 15 minutes

or something like that. But I'm hoping also
that you're going to hammer me with some questions
because it should become

apparent pretty
soon into my lecture that I don't have a perfect
understanding of what's going on in biology, either
from the standpoint of science

or from the standpoint
of engineering. And so we'll see how that goes. The second part of what I
want to talk about today

is using that knowledge and
understanding of biology as a science to then
turn it around and really

go design and build or engineer
new biological systems. This gets called a bunch
of different things.

Most recently in,
you know, these days it's called synthetic biology. You've got a little comic
strip that can provide

some background introduction. So again, two topics-- how do biological
systems compute how might you think about that and
then given an understanding

of biology, how would you start
to go engineer living systems? That sound OK?
All right.  So what do we mean by compute?

What's compute? What's computing? Anybody have a good definition
they want to roll out?

Anybody use a computer?  Somebody in the back there,
you've got a computer.
What's that thing do? AUDIENCE: Compute. [LAUGHTER] DREW ENDY: What's that?

AUDIENCE: Compute. DREW ENDY: OK, so
how does it compute? What happens when it computes?

How is-- are you doing
anything different than what these fellows here are doing? AUDIENCE: Probably [INAUDIBLE].

I mean, basically no. DREW ENDY: Are they, like,
checking email or something like that? AUDIENCE: Probably not.

DREW ENDY: Uh-huh. So-- but what is it about the
computer that lets it compute? What's going on there?

[AUDIO OUT] OK. And then are you part of
the equation of computing?

Are you doing anything with the
computer that helps it compute?

You've got some input? OK, so you're giving that
machine some information. Right, so you're
defining the environment

around that machine. Then you mentioned
the CPU, something inside that box, which is taking
that information and what?

Yeah, you don't have to tell
us what you're doing, right? So you don't need to
reveal any secrets.

But it's taking that information
and processing it, right, and then depending on
what it does, then what?

It processes the
information and you never see anything, or the stuff
on the screen changes, or your computer--

makes some output. OK, so that's not a bad
working definition, right? So you could think,
what's computation?

We've got a machine-- in this case a laptop, in
this case an earlier computer. Oh, nice to come in
this morning, Brian.
How are you? So you've got this thing. It's taking an input.

Your laptop's taking an input. It's doing some processing
on the information. It's computing, and
then as it takes

the results of
those computations and does something, actuates
something, displays something

on the screen, causes the
blinds to go up and down if they were-- and so on.

So this is fine for computers,
and we're familiar with that, right? Computers compute. It's built into the
definition of the word.

What I want to do is I want
to zoom out a little bit and give you an abstract
framework for thinking

about how biological
systems compute. So we just talked about, if you
have this idea of a machine,

information is going to
come in from the environment into the machine, and
something's going to happen

or not. It depends on how the
computers program. And then that information
will eventually go away.

Maybe there'll be action. Maybe there won't. But as a general framework
for thinking about computing,

you have information coming
into the machine and information leaving. And the thing that's
interesting about computing

is you end up doing
computing over time. It's not like computing
happens instantaneously.

It's, the information comes
in, takes some time, you do some computing. And then something happens.

And so what we're going
to need to think about if we want to understand how
computing works in biology is

map this framework across
different lengths of time. And this sounds abstract,
but I'll bring it back

to something pretty
simple in a second. So the first time scale I want
you to start thinking about

is this idea of short
time scale performance, that one form of computing is
just take in some information

and do something. So for example, if you've
got a cell phone, an example of short time scale computing,
I program, I dial up Paul,

his phone. And I'd hit Enter,
and I'd call him up. So I'd be taking
some information,

putting it into the machine. The machine would be
taking some action. A cell might respond to signal
its environment, something

it wants to eat and
change how it's swimming, start moving faster or slower.

The next time scale to think
about in terms of computing is a medium time scale,
right, where you're still

taking information in
from the environment, and you're processing
that information, but you might be
adapting your behavior,

changing what you're doing. You might be learning something. So in the context
of the cell phone,

I could program
in Paul's number. I could store it. I could speak his name. And then I could have
voice-activated calling.

And this machine, having
received this information, would change its behavior
so that in the future, when

I was interacting with it again,
it would behave differently.

Neurobiological systems--
you might learn, oh, I like the burritos at Anna's.

And so over time, you're going
to keep going back there. Or I'll speak for myself-- I'll keep going back there.

So there's
information processing and biological systems
on different timescales. So let's dive in a little
bit and look quickly

at two examples of short
time scale information processing in living systems.

How many people know
what bacteria are?

OK, so bacteria are
these little critters. They're about a micron long. And they live all around.

And they do stuff. They make copies of themselves. They swim around and whatnot. So this is a movie from
Scientific American's website

made by a fellow Jeff Johnson. And what he's-- this is not a
movie of an actual bacteria.

This is a cartoon,
computer animation. And what Jeff's
trying to depict here is this process by which
bacteria are somehow

swimming through space.  You sort of admire the
computer rendering of this.

But in the context of
what we're talking about, the thing I want you to consider
is what sort of computing

is this bacterium doing, right? What do you think about it? What is it-- what
do you-- what do you see the bacteria--
first off, what's
the bacterium doing?  It's propelling itself.

And does it look like it's
just moving around randomly, or is it going somewhere?

It's going in a straight line. So that means it must be
finding something that it likes

or going for a walk or running
away from something that's trying to eat it or something.

So you can-- this is a
made-up image, right? So we can just make
up explanations for the sorts of information
processing going on.

But you can begin to imagine
that information is coming in from the environment, that
somehow this bacterium is

receiving that information,
processing it in a way that's different than the
microprocessor in the laptop

back there and then actuating
the behavior of the system-- in this case,
causing these little

hairlike things to go back and
forth in some cascade reaction.

So there's a couple
problems I want you to think about in the
context of this example.

And this is where biological
engineering comes into the fore because it turns out that this
animation is so deeply messed

up from the
standpoint of reality that if you were to think
about information processing

in the context of the stories
we were just talking about, you wouldn't get very far. So what are some of the--

can anybody think of some
problems with this movie? If somebody-- if you were
the executive producer

of this movie and
somebody showed up with this animation,
ah, check it out, this is how bacteria
swim, you'd go, huh.

I don't like it because
of the following. Anybody think of
some reasons why this might not be a good
depiction of bacterium

swimming?  So you were
mentioning before when

you were looking at
this that they're swimming in a straight line. Is that easy or hard to do?

Why would you
think it'd be hard? Can you walk in a straight line? I can walk in a straight line.

Oh, I can see. So there's no eyes
on the bacteria.

And I don't know what
sort of sensors there are. So if I had my eyes
closed, it would be harder for me to
walk in a straight line.

Is that right? Well, I don't know about that. Has anybody tried to walk
down the Infinite Corridor with your eyes closed?

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] DREW ENDY: I don't know. I don't know how
hard it would be.

But you said something
about sensors too. So you need some way of
getting the information in.

So let's say that
there's sensors all over the surface of bacterium. They're just too small,
so we can't see them.

Would you be happy
then, that you could go in a straight line?

OK, let's say there's
one sensor here. And there's another sensor back
here at the bow and the stern.

Would that let you go
in a straight line? What does somebody else think? What would you do if you
had information coming in--

if you had a ship,
and you're trying to go in a straight
line, and you had a sensor at the front
of the ship and a sensor

at the back of the ship, could
you go in a straight line if you were sensing
something in the environment?

What would those two
inputs let you do?

So if you had something
in the environment, and you wanted to, say,
run away from something, there might be more
of it behind you

than there is in front of you. And so you could go, huh,
there's more back there.

So let's keep going this way. Maybe that would work, right? So you could use the sensor
in the back and the sensor

in the front to establish a
gradient or a directionality of a signal in the
environment and then do

some computing using the
molecules of the cell to make a decision about
which direction to go.

So, OK, maybe that's a
pretty good idea, right? We're beginning to
develop some model for how

the information in the
environment around this cell might establish some useful
framework for the cell

to do computing to
control its behavior. Anybody see a problem
with that model?
How big is this cell? How big are bacteria?

Are they like meter long? You run into bacterium
in between classes,

sort of get out of the way?  So it turns out bacterium
are really tiny.

They're a micron,
approximately, long. And so even if you put
a sensor here and here,

if this is only a micron
long, the thing you're sensing is going to be freely diffusing
in the environment around you,

which means that you might
not be long enough to actually measure the gradient.

You're not going to
be able to sense it. There's another problem
with this movie. The artist here,
it's a brilliant--

it's a brilliant piece
of work, but the artist hasn't captured the
physical framework correctly around the bacteria.

There's no eyes. So how are you going to
walk in a straight line? You're not long enough,
so you can't actually

set up a gradient directly. The other thing is,
because they're so small, there's going to be
water molecules buffeting

this bacteria randomly,
Brownian motion. And so even if you could
start off in a straight line,

I want to go over
here, things are going to be bumping into the cell. And you're going
to randomly lose the direction you were going in.

And so you're going to
have to reconstitute over and over again, I want
to be going that way, I want to be going
that way, I want

to be-- so it's a weird
physical system, right? I'm not going to go through
any more details of this.

But if you want to start
thinking about computing in biology, you need
to imagine what's

the information in the
environment around the cell, what's the physical framework by
which that information is going

to make it into the
cell, how might the cell do the computing, and
then decide what to do.

And so you can start to imagine
how physics and mathematics come together in
biological engineering

to develop the frameworks by
which you don't just understand the molecules that make
up living systems-- you understand how all these
molecules come together

to control the behavior
of living systems. So let me show you
real quick a movie

of actual bacteria swimming. This comes from
Howard Berg's work. Howard's in biology at
Harvard, as well as physics.

So what you're looking at here
are E. coli swimming around. And you can see they
really truck, right? They're quite impressive
little critters.

But if you look at it, you'll
say, whoa, what are they doing? They're not going in
straight lines, for one.
You just follow some. Let's see. Let the movie reset here.

See these cells? They're sort of like, whoa. Or check it out, they're
just looping around.

They can't go in
a straight line. They're trying to figure out how
to go somewhere, and sometimes

they just, like, spin
around and stuff like that.

And if you look at them a little
more closely in this movie, you start to see that that
flagella, those things that

were hanging behind them, are
doing all sorts of weird stuff. Sometimes they're going
in a straight line,

spinning all together. Sometimes they start spinning
in the other direction. They splay out, and the
whole cell spins around.

It turns out that what these
bacteria are going to do is they're going to
alternate between swimming

in a straight line as best they
can, which isn't that good. And then they're going to
sometimes tumble randomly.

And they're just going to
alternate between doing that, back and forth-- swimming,
tumbling, swimming, tumbling.

And they're going to change
the length of the run, how long they go in a straight
line as best they can,

in proportion to whether
or not they believe they're going in the right direction. So to say it
differently, bacterium

might start out swimming. It'll remember what the
concentration of something was here. And then it'll move,
and it'll say, oh,

is it getting better or worse? And if it's getting
worse, maybe you'll tumble and just try
another random direction.

And if it's getting
better, they'll just keep going in that
direction a little bit longer. But then eventually you
have to tumble again.

And you'll try randomly
sampling a new direction. So it's a random walk
that the bacterium end up using in order to go up or down
a gradient of something they

like. Interesting information
processing problems. Here's another one,
not from bacterium,

but this time from you. So this is a picture
of a white blood cell

in a field of red blood cells. And this is a little bacteria
that the white blood cell

would like to hunt
down and destroy to keep you from getting sick. So check this
movie out and think

about the information
processing that's going on here.

Notice that it
locked onto this one. It didn't pay any
attention to this one. How'd it do that?

Is the bacterium running
away, do you think? Or is it being pushed away by
the boundary layer of fluid

as the white blood
cell chases it? What's the right physics?

How does the cell
do this computation? Imagine you were trying
to program a missile to follow a plane, the
computation you'd have to do,

find the target,
change your trajectory. All of that's going on here in
this white blood cell, right?

All of this is happening inside
you whenever you're infected.

Pretty cool problem, right? AUDIENCE: Is this real time? DREW ENDY: I think
this is real time. I can't remember. It's a very old movie, actually.

It's a 16-millimeter
film from 1950 something.

You should be able to estimate
whether it's real time or not by the apparent tumbling rate
of the bacterium and Brownian
motion, right?

Pretty impressive computation.  So those are examples
of physical performance.

You just got to take
in a signal and do something, or medium
time scale performance--

learning, or am I going
in the right direction? Is this a bacterium I want
to hunt down and destroy?

And so you can start to think
about computing in biology. Although, the thing to say
about biology in addition

to these two examples that
makes it incredibly cool is that biology does computing
on additional time scale,

and you don't see
this time scale in any other physical
artifact that you engineer.

This additional time scale is
the long time scale, the time scale of evolution, right?

So evolution is
this process, as you would have heard previously-- biological systems,
via a replication

of the DNA, and
replication of the organism can make copies, parent
to child and so on.

Now, what's cool about biology
is when biological systems copy themselves, they make mistakes.

There are mutations in
the copying process. And so over long time scales
and with big populations,

the machine itself can change. Information will come in
in the form of selection

presented by the environment. It's good to be tall or short in
the next 100 years-- who knows?

And over time those mutations
will be fixed into the machine, defining and changing
the machine itself.

And you can view the
process of evolution as a process of computation.

Here's an example. This is a depiction of part
of the human chromosome.

This is a region of the human
chromosome found in males. It's the male-specific Y region.

This subsequence of
the human chromosome was figured out by David
Page's group at the Whitehead

across the parking lot there. Now, the thing about
the Y chromosome is that the architecture of
it from the standpoint of--

speaking as an engineer,
not as a scientist-- the architecture
of this is really messed up, which may or may
not be surprising to you

if you think about stuff. So what I mean by that is you've
got about 5 million base pairs

of DNA. DNA is the genetic material,
and As, Ts, Cs, and Gs, those are the base pairs. So you got about 5 million
base pairs of DNA on the screen

here. This region of DNA in yellow,
about 800,000 base pairs, is exactly the same as
this region, almost exactly

the same, except it's in
the opposite orientation. So I've got an
element over here,

and I've got a repeated
element over here. Similarly, this region, B4, is
like this, and these regions

here, and so on and so on. So I've got an architecture
of inverted repeats

that are nested.  Now, turns out that
there's a couple of different models for
why the Y chromosome might

have this architecture. One reason is, the
thing about the Y, unlike other-- the
male-specific region of the Y,

is that there's not
a complementary copy of this region of DNA on another
chromosome, on the X, right?

And because there's no backup
copy on another chromosome, the argument goes
that the Y needs

to be carrying two copies
of its DNA on itself so that on evolutionary
time scale,

it can swap in copies for one
another as a way of getting rid of mistakes.

So if there's a mistake over
here, maybe if I'm lucky, I can swap this piece
back in and replace it.

So the Y is carrying a
backup copy of itself in, perhaps, parts of itself.

And so you can go, huh, I
wonder if other Y chromosomes are doing that, right? So here's a paper that came
out from Japan last month

where they were looking at the
Y chromosome of the chimp, which

is shown down here. And then this is
another depiction of what we were just
looking at, the human. And then you can estimate what
the common ancestral Y was.

And then you can estimate
what the earlier ancestor Y is, right? So you can start to think about
this problem of replication

of a machine on evolutionary
time scales, mutation and selection impacting the
processing of that information

of the computation, and then
as a scientist or an engineer, developing a framework
that would let you go

from the things you see today. This is what the
human Y looks like. This is what the chimp
Y looks like I wonder

what the ancestor looked like. I wonder what the thing before
that looked like, right?

How would you start to
think about that stuff? So biological systems are
interesting computing machines.

They compute on
short time scale. They answer phone calls.

They say, I want
to eat that thing.  They process information
on medium time scales.

They learn stuff. They forget things. They change their
behavior, and then they process information on
evolutionary time scales.

Right, so at the intersection
of science and engineering, you find a whole bunch of
interesting computation

to figure out and to do. So in this triangle that I think
is a theme through the class

is sort of operating down here
along the edge between science and engineering.

So that's a quick introduction
to computational biology from the perspective of,
what sort of computing

are biological systems
themselves doing? Anybody have any thoughts
or questions about that?

Everybody buy the
three time scales of information processing
for biological systems, or are there five
that I forget to do?

Don't know, right? Still trying to figure
this out myself.

So if you pursue a career
in biological engineering, there's a lot of good
contributions to be made.

So I want to switch
gears and just imagine what the world's like in
the context of, well, yeah,

living systems exist in nature,
and we got to figure them out. But there's another
thing you could do.

You could start to engineer
biological systems directly. So that's what I'm going
to switch gears and talk

about for the next
20 minutes or so. And to put this in
perspective as best

I can from the
40,000 foot view, I want to make the
argument that there's

three relationships that human
beings can have with the living world. OK, the first relationship
goes all the way back

before Darwin,
hundreds of years ago, where people think that
living systems exist, and they don't change.

That's what everybody believed.  There was a
Scientific Revolution,

a transition here where Darwin
and colleagues come along. They figure out the
process of evolution.

They go, biological
systems exist all right. They come from nature,
but they change, and they change via this
process of reproduction

with error and
selection via evolution. And here's the
third relationship

you can have with
the living world. This is a technical transition.

Biological systems exist in
the natural living world, sure. They change via evolution. But although-- oh, by the
way, we can make new ones.

And I'll show you
how to do that. And we can make them
via design process that may approach rational.

I won't go into
this one right now. And this is a transition
which is driven by technology. It's not a scientific
transition.

It's just, can we do it or not? And it's one that's started
up about 30 years ago when

it became possible
to directly edit DNA. And it's, as you can
imagine, the first day

of class at MIT with course
20 as a course number starting to happen ever more quickly.

Here's a quick example. This is a depiction of
the genome of a virus that I've studied for the
last 12 years ago, or so.

It's a virus that infects
bacterium and just destroys them. And there's a bunch of genes
and regulatory elements,

and let's not go
into all the details.  One of the things we do is
we make computational models

of the infection process. So what you're looking at
here is gene expression as the virus is infecting
a bacterium, RNA polymerase

molecules reading
out the DNA, proteins and stuff getting made. This is the best
computer simulation

we've got for gene
expression inside bacteria. We can track individual
molecules of RNA polymerase

with single base pair resolution
on the DNA, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, right? Run it on the computer,
get all these numbers

and stuff like that. It's a simulation, right? You can run it
backwards, and we can use this to study the
infection process of the virus.

Without going into
the details, let me simply declare that this
computer model is woefully

insufficient to predict
how the virus is going to behave when we
change it or when it evolves.

So even though this is an
incredibly powerful tool, we've run into lots of
problems as we try and make

the mapping between the
computer models of how the biological
system will behave and the actual physical
performance in the lab.

And if you think about it from
the standpoint of engineering,

why the models aren't quite
good enough in biology, there's some interesting
conclusions you can come to.

The most interesting one
for me as an engineer is that biology itself is
not optimized, by nature,

to be easy to model because
nature doesn't care about that.

Let me give you some examples. This is the list of genes
that make up the virus.

There are about 60 genes. The ones that are highlighted
in this color, those

are the ones for which
we don't know anything about those genes,
about 40% of the genes.

So that's sort of-- and, oh, by the way, it's not
just me because I'm stupid, it's-- which is true. But it's, nobody on the planet
knows what these genes do.

So it's sort of like you
open up the hood of your car, and you go what's that? Don't know.

With your car, you can
go talk to the mechanic or the person who made the
car, and somebody on the planet

knows. In this case, I open up the hood
on the genome of this virus, and about 40% of the things,
nobody knows what they do.

So how am I going to model or
understand or engineer a system where 40% of the components are
completely mysterious to me?

Maybe I can do it, but
it's going to be a trip. That's a problem. I'm going to declare--

from a standpoint
of engineering, I'm going to declare that to
be unsatisfying about biology. Where do all these
things come from?

Don't know. Here's a second problem. Let's look at the DNA
sequence, just for a sec.

If you're programming
your computer, sometimes you might want to
think about zeros and ones. So here we're looking at
the As, Gs, Cs, and Ts.

So here's a stretch
of virus DNA. And there's a region right here
that comes in from the left and stops.

And that encodes
this protein, 2.8. Don't worry about these details.

Just grok the big picture. Here's another gene 3. It starts at this
green sequence, ATG,

and goes off to the right. So what's curious about the real
estate on this virus's genome

is that the two coding regions,
the two genes, overlap. They share real estate.

It's not like a
time share condo. I mean, they physically share-- they occupy the same
space on the DNA.

I have no idea
what's going on here. Is this some important,
functional coupling

that controls the reading out
of the genetic information? Maybe. It's a big problem. It's just as bad as having an
unknown part, this coupling.

The other problem is,
if I want to change this to test a
prediction, I can't

change gene 3 in this region
without also changing gene 2.8.

I can't independently
manipulate one thing. So it would be like, I
make a phone call here,

and my computer crashes. Or you increase the volume
of your radio in your car,

and the steering
wheel starts to move. You've got coupling
of components.

Here's a depiction of-- so the question I want
to pose to you is why? Why might the systems
look like that?

So here's a depiction of
an electrical circuit. Is anybody taking 6001 or
6002 or stuff like that?

It meets right now,
so you can't take it. OK. So this is your surrogate
for 6002, right?

So this is a scheme of
an electrical circuit. I can assure you
that nobody in 6002

can explain to you how
this circuit works. You want to know why? Why do you think that is?

Turns out that
this circuit wasn't designed by a human being. It was designed by an
evolutionary computer program.

So you can simulate
evolution on a computer, and you can simulate
electrical circuits well enough that
you can actually

evolve electrical
circuits to do stuff. So this is a circuit that came
out of an evolutionary program,

and the design of
this circuit is supposed to produce
something that takes the square root
of an input voltage.

That's it. And when I go talk to Jerry
Sussman in core 6, who's a great friend, I say, Jerry,
how does this work, he goes--

he doesn't say I don't know. He goes, I refuse to
work on the problem.

It's not-- what? I refuse to work on the
problem of figuring out how this works because it wasn't
designed for it to be easy

for me to figure
out how it works.  What if biological
systems are like that?

Does that mean he won't
try and figure out how biological systems work? Well, maybe he can't
do the same thing

unless he has the option of
building biological systems.

So I'll switch over to that. So for example, instead of
accepting this piece of DNA

from nature, maybe
I can replace it with this piece of DNA, which
is an engineered surrogate,

a replacement, where
I take the gene for 3, and I put it over here.
